questions.text:
A patient is suspected to have renal tubular acidosis. His lab parameters show elevated potassium levels and metabolic acidosis. Identify the correct pair describing the diagnosis from the following options.

RTA - Renal Tubular Acidosis

choices.text: Renal tubular acidosis 1 - Impaired H+ secretion
Renal tubular acidosis 2 - Impaired HCO3- reabsorption

questions.solution:
Renal tubular acidosis 4 - hypoaldosteronism is the correct pair that explains the diagnosis of the given patient.

RTA 4 (hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis) is associated with aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium excretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders with impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.

Other options:

Option A: RTA 4 causes features of hypoaldosteronism and not hyperaldosteronism. So, this option is incorrect.

Option B: RTA 1 (Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition is characterised by impaired acid secretion in the distal renal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to the compensatory secretion of potassium to maintain electroneutrality. 

Option D: RTA 2 (Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition involves impaired bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to urinary losses of potassium.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing evaluation for an inherited renal tubular disorder. Physical examination showed normal blood pressure. Further tests showed metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia with hypercalciuria. The affected part of this disorder is  ___
questions.solution:
The affected part of this disorder is the ascending limb of Henle. The clinical scenario of a renal tubular disorder causing polyuria, polydipsia, normal blood pressure, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia with hypercalciuria is suggestive of Bartters syndrome. Inherited renal tubular disorders are a diverse group of genetic conditions affecting the renal tubules.

Bartter Syndrome is a group of 4 disorders affecting sodium, potassium, and chloride channels in the thick ascending limb of Henle.  It causes hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, hypercalciuria, and normal to low blood pressure.

Other options:

Option A: Distal convoluted tubule: Gitelman syndrome affects the distal convoluted tubule due to a mutation in the gene encoding the thiazide-sensitive Na-Cl cotransporter. It causes hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis.

Option C: Proximal convoluted tubule: A generalized reabsorption defect in the proximal convoluted tubule causes glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, bicarbonaturia, and proximal renal tubular acidosis (type II). This happens in Fanconi Syndrome, which can be associated with genetic conditions like cystinosis, Lowe syndrome, Wilson disease, and galactosemia. 

Option D: Collecting Duct: The epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the collecting ducts are affected in Liddle Syndrome. It is pseudohyperaldosteronism due to mutations in the SCNN1B or SCNN1G genes leading to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was referred to cardiology OPD for the management of hypertension. His BP was not controlled with spironolactone and laboratory investigations revealed hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. His BP comes down when spironolactone is replaced with amiloride. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, responding to amiloride but not spironolactone, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome (also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism) is most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone. Although its presentation is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone is nearly undetectable in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism.

Other options:

Option A: Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) occurs due to the activation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol, like in 11-β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. It also presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but mineralocorticoid receptor blockade with spironolactone is successful in treating SAME. Spironolactone does not work in Liddle syndrome because the defect is downstream to where spironolactone acts.

Option C: Addison's disease refers to adrenal insufficiency and decreased levels of aldosterone. It presents with hyponatremic volume contraction (which may lead to hypotension), hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: An infant under evaluation was found to have autosomal recessive defects in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase II. The diagnosis of Marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome is made. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestation that is not typically associated with marble brain disease (osteopetrosis) is osteopenia.

Osteopenia refers to lower-than-normal bone density but is not a feature of marble brain disease, which is characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone formation (osteopetrosis).

Marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a defect in osteoclasts, leading to excessive bone formation and brittle, dense bones. It is due to an autosomal recessive, inherited carbonic anhydrase-2 (CA-2) deficiency. Carbonic anhydrase II is required by osteoclasts and renal tubular cells to generate protons from carbon dioxide and water (acidification). The absence of carbonic anhydrase II prevents osteoclasts from acidifying the resorption pit and dissolution of calcium hydroxyapatite within the bone matrix. It also blocks the acidification of urine by the renal tubular cells. This leads to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis.

This abnormal bone growth can result in various clinical manifestations.

  • Cerebral calcifications
  • Mental retardation 
  • Cranial nerve defects
  • Mixed RTA (Type 3 RTA)
  • Osteopetrosis

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the likely underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Fanconi syndrome presents with type 2 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and causes hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Type 2 RTA occurs because of a defect in the proximal tubule HCO3- reabsorption. There is increased excretion of HCO3-, leading to metabolic acidosis. There is increased delivery of the tubular fluid to the distal tubule, leading to increased Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion in the distal tubule under the effect of aldosterone. Note that the effect of HCO3- loss overpowers the H+ loss in the distal tubule due to aldosterone, and thus the net result is metabolic acidosis. The urine pH is mostly <5.5 because of the depletion of the HCO3- stores in the body, but it can be >5.5 early in the disease course due to excess filtered HCO3-. The causes of type 2 RTA include Fanconi syndrome, multiple myeloma, and Wilson's disease.

Other options:

Option B: Gitelman syndrome causes increased fluid delivery to the distal tubule, leading to more Na+ absorption, and increased H+ and K+ secretion under the influence of aldosterone. Thus, it causes metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.

Option C: Bartter syndrome also causes increased Na+ absorption, and increased H+ and K+ secretion under the influence of aldosterone, thus, causing metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.

 Option D:  Liddle syndrome occurs due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC channels in the distal tubule. It also causes metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia by similar mechanisms.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is administered in the management of a patient with proximal renal tubular acidosis?
questions.solution:
A combination of sodium and potassium citrate is administered in the management of a patient with proximal renal tubular acidosis. Here, citrate acts as a source of bicarbonate ions.

Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is caused by the defective reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal tubule. Administration of alkali to correct the bicarbonate loss causes hypokalemia and hence potassium is given along with a source of bicarbonate ions. Proximal RTA is usually associated with Fanconi syndrome characterized by glycosuria, phosphaturia, and aminoaciduria in addition to bicarbonaturia.

Fludrocortisone (Option B), furosemide (Option C), and Patiromer (Option D) (calcium-potassium cation exchange polymer) are administered in generalised distal RTA (type 4 RTA) to correct hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has complaints of marked dryness in her mouth associated with difficulty in swallowing. Schirmer's test is suggestive of severe dry eye. An immunoassay shows the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies. Which of the following types of renal tubular acidosis is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms together with the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome. Type 1 (distal) RTA can be seen in this patient.

The causes of type 1 RTA are as follows

Primary

  • Sporadic
  • Inherited (autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive)

Secondary

  • Systemic genetic diseases such as osteoporosis, elliptocytosis, Ehler-Danlos syndrome, Primary hyperoxaluria type 2
  • Acquired conditions such as
    • Autoimmune diseases: Sjogren's syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, hyperglobulinemia
    • Renal transplantation
    • Medullary sponge kidney
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Malnutrition
    • Drugs and toxics - amphotericin B, lithium salts, amiloride, toluene

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with recurrent kidney stones composed of calcium oxalate. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of oxalate in the urine. Genetic testing confirms deficiency of enzyme alanine glyoxalate transferase. Which of the following is not a management option in this condition?
questions.solution:
The adolescent boy described has primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1), a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase (AGT). Loop diuretics are not a management option in this condition.

Primary hyperoxaluria type 1 results in excessive oxalate production, due to a genetic deficiency of the enzyme alanine glyoxalate transferase, leading to high levels of oxalate in the urine (hyperoxaluria). The excess oxalate can combine with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals, which can deposit in the kidneys and other organs, leading to recurrent kidney stones, nephrocalcinosis, and potentially end-stage renal disease. Loop diuretics increase calcium excretion in the urine, potentially exacerbating the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

The enzyme alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase helps in the conversion of glyoxylic acid to glycine. In the absence of this enzyme glyoxylic acid is transferred to the cytoplasm and is oxidized to oxalic acid.

Presenting symptoms include colicky abdominal pain, hematuria dysuria, etc. There is gradual deterioration of renal function which manifests as growth failure and uremia. Other manifestations include failure to thrive, short stature, arterial calcifications, arrhythmia, heart failure, hypothyroidism, and skin nodules.

Treatment options include increased fluid intake, pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), potassium or sodium citrate, dietary modifications, thiazide diuretics, orthophosphate, and in severe cases, liver and kidney transplantation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with muscle weakness, abnormal tingling sensation over the face, and pain and swelling over the knee joint for 3 months. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Investigations show hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria with metabolic alkalosis. His x-ray knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with muscle weakness, paresthesia over the face, hypotension, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, metabolic alkalosis, and x-ray knee showing chondrocalcinosis as punctate density on the cartilage are suggestive of Gitelman's syndrome. 

Gitelman's syndrome is an autosomal recessive salt-losing renal tubulopathy. It occurs due to a mutation of Na+-Cl– co-transporter (NCCT) in the distal tubule. 

NCCT helps in the absorption of sodium and chloride ions from the lumen of the distal tubule. In Gitelman's syndrome, due to the loss of function of NCCT, there will be increased sodium and chloride delivery to collecting duct and volume retraction. This results in increased renin and aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone act on epithelial sodium channels in the collecting duct causing increased reabsorption of sodium and increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

Downregulation of magnesium-permeable channels in Gitelman syndrome leads to urinary loss of magnesium resulting in hypomagnesemia.

There is increased passive reabsorption of calcium in the proximal convoluted tubule in Gitelman syndrome resulting in hypocalciuria. 

Hypomagnesemia impairs the function of calcitropic hormones and down-regulates the normal inverse association between ionized calcium, parathyroid hormone, and calcitriol. This results in reduced skeletal sensitivity of PTH and impaired intestinal calcium transport and explains the lack of hypercalcemia response to hypocalciuria. 

Low magnesium levels result in the reduction of pyrophosphate activity that could promote pyrophosphate crystallization in joints causing joint pains and chondrocalcinosis.

Even though patients present above the age of 6 years, the diagnosis in most cases is established during adulthood. Patients often present with signs of tetany, paresthesias, and chondrocalcinosis, as a result of hypomagnesemia and fatiguability. 

Hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia prolong the duration of the action potential of cardiomyocytes and consequently increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmia. 

Other options:

Option A: Bartter's syndrome affects the Na+/K+/Cl-  co-transporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It causes hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Liddle's syndrome causes increased activation of epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) channels expressed on the apical membrane of principal cells of the collecting duct. It results in severe hypertension with hypokalemia.

Option D: Fanconi's syndrome occurs due to a defect in the proximal tubular function that prevents the absorption of electrolytes and other substances that are normally absorbed by the proximal tubule. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: An obese diabetic patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. His arterial blood pH is 7.2 and his urine is positive for glucose and ketones. His blood glucose level is 130 mg/dL. Which anti-diabetic drug was the patient likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis with euglycemia, which is an adverse effect of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors such as canagliflozin. 

Inhibition of SGLT2 and consequent decrease in blood glucose levels stimulates glucagon. Glucagon increases the production of glucose and ketones in the liver. SGLT2 inhibitors can cause euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) because of the increased excretion of glucose in the urine. Euglycemic DKA can occur at times of stress or when ongoing glycosuria masks the stress-induced requirements of insulin. This is why SGLT2 inhibitors should not be prescribed to patients with type I diabetes mellitus or pancreatogenic forms of diabetes mellitus which are associated with insulin deficiency.

SGLT2 is a Na+-glucose cotransporter that is located in the proximal convoluted tubule of the kidney. They reabsorb glucose and sodium from the tubular lumen back into the blood through the epithelial cells. SGLT2 inhibitors block the transport of glucose in the proximal tubule and promote glycosuria and hence lower blood glucose. The currently available SGLT2 inhibitors are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin. Other than decreasing blood glucose they also decrease systolic blood pressure and cause weight loss. Empagliflozin and canagliflozin reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events in patients with established diabetes mellitus. All SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce the incidence of hospitalization in CHF and reduced the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

The main side effect of SGLT2 inhibitors because of their glycosuric properties is an increase in lower urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections. Dapagliflozin is associated with a possible risk of bladder cancer, while canagliflozin is associated with an increased risk of fractures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Type II Diabetes mellitus on insulin comes for a routine examination. Physical examination reveals an ulcer on the base of the great toe, pulse rate - 80/minute, blood pressure - 140/80 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations show HbA1c of 6.7% and findings consistent with renal tubular acidosis type IV. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Type IV renal tubular acidosis (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism) may occur in Type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus. Decreased urinary excretion of ammonium will be seen in these patients.

Causes for decreased renin activity that is commonly seen in patients with diabetes mellitus:

  • Injury to the juxtaglomerular apparatus (like afferent arteriolar hyalinization)
  • Defects in the stimulation factors and defective conversion of prorenin to renin
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Increase in renal salt retention with volume expansion, which suppresses renin synthesis paradoxically when compared to patients without DM
  • An increase in the secretion of atrial natriuretic peptide in these patients suppresses both renin and aldosterone.

The clinical features seen in Type IV RTA are:

  • Hyperkalemia: Aldosterone increases the number of open sodium channels which leads to reabsorption of sodium. This in turn creates an electrochemical gradient that favours the secretion of potassium. In the absence of this effect due to low aldosterone, there will be an increase in potassium concentration
  • Metabolic acidosis: Due to diminished ammonium production in the proximal tubule, decreased ammonium excretion, and impaired NH4 transport.
  • Urinary pH<5.5: The principal buffers in the urine are ammonia and phosphate. Hyperkalemia seen in RTA Type 4 causes impaired ammonia genesis in the proximal tubule and reduces the availability of NH3 to buffer H+ ions. This decreased ammonia leads to excess protons in the renal tubules decreasing the urinary pH.

Causes of Type IV RTA:

  • Diabetes and renal insufficiency
  • NSAIDs
  • Calcineurin inhibitors
  • Angiotensin inhibitors
  • Heparin and low-molecular-weight heparin
  • Primary adrenal insufficiency
  • Severe illness
  • Inherited conditions
    • Congenital isolated hypoaldosteronism
    • Pseudohypoaldosteronism Type 2 (Gordon's syndrome)
  • Aldosterone resistance
    • Potassium-sparing diuretics
    • Antibiotics: Trimethoprim and pentamidine
    • Pseudohypoaldosteronism Type 1

questions.text:
The ABG findings of a patient are given below. Which of the following metabolic abnormality is present in this patient?

PaCO2: 35 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L

pH: 7.50

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given scenario reveals metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of ABG:

Step 1:

Value in the question Normal value Interpretation
pH = 7.50 (7.35 – 7.45) 7.4 Increased
paCO2 = 35  (35 – 45) 40 Normal
HCO3- = 30  (22 – 28) 25 Increased

The values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Step 2:

Calculating the respiratory compensation:

In metabolic alkalosis, Compensation formula is as follows:

∆ [HCO3-] = Increase in HCO3-, in above case is  = 30 - 25 = 5

So, compensatory increase of CO2 should be = 0.7 x 5 = 3.5

Applying the above, the compensation value of CO2 should lie between

40 + 3.5 = 43.5 or approx. 44

Taking +/- 3 into consideration,  Compensatory values of CO2 = 41 – 47

Step 3:

Since CO2 = 35 which is below the compensatory values, hence this is not compensated.

It suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4:

Looking for anion gap:

Anion gap should be looked for only in cases of:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal pH

Since the primary disorder is metabolic alkalosis, anion gap is not looked into.

A situation like this is seen with liver disease and diuretics administration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, diagnosed with bipolar disorder is under treatment with lithium for the past 2 months. She now presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination and a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus was made. The administration of desmopressin did not increase the specific gravity of urine. Which is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) is amiloride.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index hence regular determination of serum concentrations is important. Its use is approved by FDA in acute mania and the prevention of recurrences of bipolar illness in adults or adolescents.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • CNS toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into collecting duct cells and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI.

Other options:

Option A: Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory sodium as well as lithium reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Option C: Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Thiazide diuretics also lead to lithium toxicity.

Option D: Chlorpropamide is a long-acting oral sulfonylurea preferred for central diabetes insipidus owing to its enhancing action on circulating vasopressin.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presented with the deformity shown in the image. Subsequent investigations revealed a mutation in the PHEX gene and increased levels of fibroblast growth factor-23 (FGF 23). Which of the following is the likely set of reports for the patient?
  S. phosphate S. Calcium  S. PTH pH
1 Low Normal High Low
2 High Low High Normal
3 Low Low High Normal
4 Low Normal Normal Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing the wind-swept deformity (characteristic of rickets in a pediatric patient) and PHEX gene mutation is suggestive of X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets. This patient's laboratory reports will show low phosphate levels, normal calcium levels, parathyroid hormone levels, and normal pH. 

Hypophosphatemic rickets:

X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on x chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased. This is impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate.

Other causes of hypophosphatemic rickets include:

  • Autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets
  • Autosomal recessive hypophosphatemic rickets
  • Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria
  • Tumor-induced rickets
  • Fanconi Syndrome

The chart attached below summarizes the evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets:


Patients respond well to a combination of oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). The daily need for phosphorus supplementation is 1–3 g of elemental phosphorus divided into 4–5 doses. Frequent dosing helps prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus levels because there is a rapid decline after each dose. In addition, frequent dosing decreases diarrhea, which is a complication of high-dose oral phosphorus. Calcitriol is administered 30–70 ng/kg/day divided into 2 doses. 

Further, Joulie's solution is also useful in the treatment of familial hypophosphatemic rickets. Joulie's solution includes contains 30.4 mg of phosphate/mL. The most common side effect is diarrhea. 

Other options:

Option A is seen in proximal renal tubular acidosis (Type 2 RTA). Serum phosphate is low due to phosphate wasting, serum calcium is usually normal, serum PTH is elevated due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, and urine pH is initially acidic but may become less acidic as bicarbonate loss worsens, resulting in metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Option B can be seen in rickets associated with chronic renal failure. Serum phosphate levels are typically elevated due to impaired renal excretion. Serum calcium levels may be low or normal because the kidneys are unable to produce sufficient active vitamin D, leading to impaired calcium absorption and phosphate retention. Serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are elevated due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which occurs as a compensatory response to low calcium and high phosphate and pH levels in the blood may be normal or low, reflecting the presence of metabolic acidosis often associated with reduced kidney function.

Option C shows the set of reports in the case of nutritional rickets. It commonly occurs due to the deficiency of vitamin D, thereby affecting the metabolism of calcium and phosphate ions in the body. In vitamin D deficiency, low calcium levels may be seen in the blood. To raise serum calcium levels, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone (PTH) rises. 

Related Pearl: Vitamin D activation and Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text:
What is incorrect regarding aminoglycoside-mediated nephrotoxicity?

AKI - Acute Kidney Injury

choices.text: AKI can present even after the drug is discontinued

questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides cause non-oliguric (urine volume >400 mL/day) acute kidney injury (AKI).

Aminoglycoside-mediated nephrotoxicity:

  • It causes tubular necrosis.
  • It causes non-oliguric AKI.
  • It is freely filtered across the glomerulus and accumulates within the renal cortex.
  • AKI occurs after 5–7 days of therapy, and it can present even after the drug has been discontinued. 
  • Hypomagnesemia is a common finding.

Nephrotoxic drugs include the following:

  • NSAIDs: Prerenal AKI > acute tubulointerstitial nephritis
  • Antifungals (amphotericin B): Acute tubular necrosis
  • Antibiotics
    • Aminoglycosides: Acute tubular necrosis
    • Vancomycin: AKI
    • Cephalosporins: Acute interstitial nephritis
    • Sulfonamides: Acute interstitial nephritis 
  • Antivirals
    • Acyclovir: Precipitates in tubules and causes obstruction, hence oliguric AKI
    • Foscarnet: Tubular toxicity
  • Chemotherapy drugs
    • Ifosfamide: Hemorrhagic cystitis and tubular toxicity. 
    • Platins: Necrosis and apoptosis of proximal tubular cells.
  • Immunosuppressants (cyclosporine)

questions.text: The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis is:

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. 

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which acidosis occurs because of the inability of the tubules of the kidney to perform normal functions required to maintain acid-base balance. In this disorder, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is relatively well-preserved.

The defect is either inability to excrete hydrogen ions (inadequate generation of new bicarbonate ions) or inadequate reabsorption of bicarbonate ions. 

Types of RTA:

  • Type I - distal RTA or classical RTA is characterised by the inability to excrete H+ ions by the distal nephron. The urinary pH is >5.5, as the urine cannot be fully acidified, despite systemic acidosis. 
  • Type II - proximal RTA is characterised by the inability to reabsorb filtered bicarbonate by the proximal tubule.
  • Type III - mixed type, similar to both type I and II.
  • Type IV - is the most common type of RTA in clinical practice. This is a disorder of hyperkalemia, that occurs due to decreased aldosterone, which inhibits ammonium production.

The anion gap is the difference between readily measured anions and cations. The normal anion gap is 12 ± 4 mEq/L. The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types of RTA is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal. This kind of metabolic abnormality is also seen in gastrointestinal losses.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with weakness and fatigue. On examination, her blood pressure is low. Laboratory investigations reveal metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, and high urine chloride. Based on these findings, which of the following renal ion channels are affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of Gitelman syndrome caused by mutations in the NaCl Co-transporter (sodium chloride cotransporter) located in the distal convoluted tubule. Excessive renal wasting of sodium, chloride, and potassium, leads to hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. Other hallmark laboratory findings include hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, and high urine chloride levels.

Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive salt-losing renal tubulopathy. Patients often present with signs of tetany, paresthesias, and chondrocalcinosis. NCCT helps in the absorption of sodium and chloride ions from the lumen of the distal tubule. Due to the loss of function of NCCT, there will be increased sodium and chloride delivery to the collecting duct and volume retraction, leading to increased renin and aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone acts on epithelial sodium channels in the collecting duct causing increased reabsorption of sodium and increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. 

Despite increased renin and aldosterone levels, patients generally have low/normal blood pressure.

Increased urinary loss of magnesium results in hypomagnesemia and increased passive reabsorption of calcium in the proximal convoluted tubule results in hypocalciuria. 

Other options: 

Option A: Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the distal tubule are affected in Liddle syndrome which occurs due to a gain of function mutation. It also causes metabolic alkalosis. There is increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension.

Option C: The defect in the Na+/K+/2Cl- Cotransporter (Sodium, Potassium Chloride Cotransporter) in the thick ascending loop of Henle is seen in Bartter syndrome which results in polyuria, polydipsia, natriuresis with high aldosterone (due to RAAS activation), hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria. The combination of hypokalemia and alkalosis in a normotensive, nonedematous patient can be due to either Bartter or Gitelman syndrome. However, the key difference in Bartter syndrome is that hypercalciuria is seen.

Option D: Sodium bicarbonate cotransporter is mutated in proximal renal tubular acidosis (Type II RTA).

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient has the following laboratory findings: pH 7.2, plasma sodium 136 mEq/L, chloride 110 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L, and potassium 2.6 mEq/L. Urine studies show a pH of 5.1. Following the administration of intravenous sodium bicarbonate, the urine pH is 5.8. Which of the following conditions is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The laboratory findings are most likely suggestive of type II (proximal) renal tubular acidosis.

The arterial blood gas analysis shows normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA).

Interpretation:

Step 1: The pH is 7.2 (<7.35) suggestive of acidosis

Step 2: Plasma bicarbonate is 15 mEq/L indicating metabolic acidosis

Step 3: Assessment of the anion gap:

 Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

= 136 - (110 + 15)

= 136 - 125

= 11 mEq/L (Normal range: 8-12 mEq/L)

Hence, the laboratory findings are suggestive of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Renal tubular acidosis is one of the common causes of NAGMA. The serum potassium is low (hypokalemia), suggestive of either type I or type II renal tubular acidosis. Type III RTA is rare and is seen mostly in children, while type IV RTA is associated with hyperkalemia.

The urine pH is initially 5.1 (<5.5, acidic), which increased to 5.8 (>5.5) following administration of sodium bicarbonate (alkali therapy), suggestive of poor bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules of the kidney, making the diagnosis of type II (proximal) renal tubular acidosis.

Type II RTA is commonly caused due to generalized proximal tubular dysfunction, associated with Fanconi syndrome (glycosuria, aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia). The bicarbonate is poorly reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule, leading to its increased excretion (bicarbonaturia). This leads to decreased plasma bicarbonate levels and metabolic acidosis.

As the plasma bicarbonate levels fall below the renal threshold for reabsorption of the HCO3- in patients with type II RTA, all the bicarbonate is reabsorbed thus maintaining the urinary pH acidic (<5.5). When sodium bicarbonate is administered intravenously, it increases the plasma bicarbonate levels above the limited renal threshold, leading to increased excretion of HCO3- causing increased urinary pH (> 5.5).

Alkali therapy for correcting plasma bicarbonate in type II RTA should be carried out with caution, as sudden increased availability of HCO3- to the distal tubules stimulates the secretion of potassium, further exaggerating the hypokalemia. Hence, potassium salts are usually administered along with alkali therapy. An oral solution of a combination of sodium and potassium citrate is commonly prescribed alkali therapy for this reason.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: The acid-base abnormality seen in Bartter's syndrome corresponds to which of the following areas of the nomogram?
questions.solution:
Bartter's syndrome leads to the loss of H+ ions resulting in metabolic alkalosis corresponding to the area marked as 'C' in the normogram.

Causes of metabolic alkalosis include:

1. Loss of hydrogen ions:

  • Removal of gastric secretions, such as in vomiting or gastric aspiration
  • Gastrocolic fistula
  • Bartter's, Gitelman's, and Liddle syndromes
  • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary hyperaldosteronism, Cushing's syndrome)

2. H+ movement into cells: Hypokalemia

3. Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of exogenous alkali
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Milk-alkali syndrome

3. Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume): loop or thiazide-type diuretics

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight male patient was referred for the evaluation of renal stones. He complains of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the preferred treatment for this man?
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content). The preferred treatment for a cystine renal calculus of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) as cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL (extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy) due to their hardness.

PCNL is the preferred treatment for -large renal stones of a diameter of more than 1.5-2.5 cm, in the presence of multiple stones, and in cases like this patient where it is a smaller, harder stone, not responsive to ESWL (like cystine, struvite, and calcium oxalate stones). 

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include haemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma, perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant, and perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track. 

Cystinuria occurs due to a hereditary defect in an amino acid transporter in the renal proximal convoluted tubule and intestine. This prevents the reabsorption of amino acids like cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. The only known complication of this disease is the formation of calculi, because of the low solubility of cystine in the urine. Cystine is more likely to precipitate in acidic urine.

Prevention of stone formation in patients with cystinuria can be done by increasing fluid intake and alkalinization of the urine with sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate. Chelating agents such as penicillamine have also been found to be useful. Tiopronin is currently the best choice drug for cystine reduction, but side effects like nephrotic syndrome may limit its long-term use. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the excretion of cystine in the urine by directly reducing its formation.

Other options-

Option (A): Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.

 Option (C): Open surgery- A longstanding obstructing calculus can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney. Open surgeries are generally indicated for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Generally, in such cases, a subcapsular nephrectomy is performed. In extremely rare cases where both PCNL and ESWL are contraindicated, one might resort to open/laparoscopic surgery. 

Option (D): Ureteroscopic removal- Semi-rigid ureteroscopes are frequently used to directly visualize ureteric calculi. Advances in the design of ureterorenoscopy have made it easier to access these stones by endoscopic examination.  Stones can also be fragmented using mechanical disintegration using the lithoclast. This method is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter.
